 Certainly a bold position to take...I salute you. I also must say that in general, I disagree. Yes, children need to be eposed to controversial ideas, it will help them learn. Many things presented in school could be considered controversial depending on what side of the argument you fall on. Like what? Evolution, world history, wars, governmental and political systems, and sex. 
 
 Other than knowing what homosexuality is, I don't really see a need for children to be "educated" on the subject. I was never formally "educated" on heterosexuality. Understanding the difference between the two lifestyles was enough for me. I felt rather cheated in sex Ed classes however. It was a 2 day inclusion in our health class, and little was discussed other than how to use a condom, and a brief anatomy and physiology lesson. Sad. There is so much more children should be taught about sex. We had very little discussion about STD's, pregnancy, and the benefits and consequences of sex. Subjects such as oral sex and anal sex were never mentioned. I think that considering that there can be significant risks associated with these (many people feel that you cannot get an STD from oral sex, and anal sex can lead to hepatitis and other diseases far more easily than any other type of sex), they should be discussed. However, since these are practiced by heterosexual as well as homosexual couples, it does not need to be a homosexual only discussion. 
 
 I think that a great majority of heterosexual education comes from the unavoidable indoctrination experienced from birth on up. It is the base feature of society, the idea that sex = man + woman. I don't really remember being taught this in school however, other than perhaps the study of Romeo and Juliet. I was lucky in the fact that our library even contained some books with homosexual themes, some of which were actually interesting reads. I also never witnessed any anti-gay sentiment in my school, despite a relatively small but open population of gay students and teachers. I just don't see that the benefits of homosexuality nor heterosexuality should be taught in a school. Of course, a child should never be ignored if they have a question about something. If the teacher feels that it is a discussion not appropriate for the classroom, it would be prudent to advise the student to ask the question later. I do think that as homosexuals exist in the world (and queerness is not a bad thing), kids who are exposed to people like this, families like this, stories about this, etc., will benefit from it. You don't necessarily have to sit kids down and "have a talk" about it or randomly insert it into the curriculum. Talking about families, sex, households, love, parents, adults, whatever, inevitably begs mention of all kinds of different communities. The more communities children are introduced to when young, the better their understanding of the world will be.
 
 I also strongly disagree with the notion that children should be sheilded from "unpleasantness", like death or controversy. Children can grasp a lot more then they are generally given credit for, and if they are not told anything they will come to their own conclusions about things- which is often not a good thing. 
 
 Keeping children imprisoned in a fake saccharine world of "happy" Christian heterosexual married rich suburbian WASPs is borderline abusive, and will only stunt their emotional and intellectual growth. They might end up spending their adult lives as bitter ranting homophobes.
